Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Inferring ecology in fossil terrestrial ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
How birds evolved their staggering ecological diversity, from vampire finches that drink blood to storm petrels that eat plankton, remains an unanswered question. Bird skeletons are infrequently preserved in the fossil record; when they are, it remains difficult to infer the habits of extinct species in ancient ecosystems. In this doctoral dissertation project, investigators will infer the diet and habitat preferences of extinct birds by comparing the morphology of their wings, legs, and beaks to that of modern birds. These inferences will be further tested in selected species by comparing the predictions made from morphology with the preserved gut contents of fossil specimens. The most diverse fossil bird assemblages are found in 125 million-year-old deposits in China and 50 million-year-old deposits in North America and Germany. By comparing the suite of ecological traits seen in birds from each of these ancient deposits with the suite seen in these localities today and in the recent past, (<1 million years ago), the researchers will develop a more complete understanding of how environmental change has contributed to global bird diversity through the processes of diversification and extinction.

Biodiversity is threatened by increasing rates of species' extinctions. Results from this study will link past environmental change with extinction, contributing valuable historical information to improve predictions of future extinction rates. Fossils are also one of the best ways to get students and the public interested in science. The investigators participate in several educational programs at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, leading 'behind the scenes' tours of fossil collections and developing professional training programs in geology and earth history for elementary school teachers. Undergraduate and high school students will participate in this project with data collection and analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are almost 10,000 species of birds. Birds are found on every continent, and from penguins swimming in the ocean to hummingbirds hovering above flowers, birds do just about everything a back-boned animal can do. All of these birds evolved from a single common ancestor. What did that ancestor look like, and how did it make its living? How did one ancestor give rise to creatures as different as ducks and ostriches? And how fast did this great diversity of species evolve?

To understand how the earliest birds, those birds most closely related to that single ancestor, made their living, we have to use fossils. But we can't follow a creature that's been extinct for 100 million years to see how it behaves and what it eats. Instead, we look at how features of the skeleton, like how long the legs are relative to the wings, or how curved the beak is, relate to things like foraging habitat and diet in modern birds. Once we know how those features relate, we can predict the diets and habits of extinct birds, and compare those predictions with fossils that preserve gut contents (fossilized last meals). These sorts of analyses tell us that the first birds from China, 120 million years ago, were mostly like quails and robins, eating seeds and insects mostly on the ground.

But the fossil record is imperfect. Not every animal that has ever lived was preserved, and many species likely left no trace in the fossil record at all. We'll almost certainly never find a fossil of *the* first bird, but are the fossil birds we do find an accurate picture of what really existed? For instance, there aren't very many duck-like birds from the early deposits. Is that because most of the birds didn't live in the water, or because the water birds didn't get preserved? Mathematical models strongly support the former. Birds that live in water are very easy to preserve, so the fact that we don't find them suggests that they really weren't around in China 120 million years ago.

By looking at the genetics of living birds, scientists have constructed giant family trees of birds, connecting almost all of the living species together based on patterns of descent from shared common ancestors. By using those family trees (phylogenies) and adding in fossil species, we can look at how quickly birds evolved from one single ancestor to the huge diversity of forms we see today. And the answer was surprisingly fast: most of the major differences seen in modern birds had evolved by the "halfway point" of bird evolution (50 million years ago). Much more evolution happened in that first half of bird history than we would ever be able to know about without fossil species.
